comments.text:
I really enjoyed this video; it is one of my favorite Numberphile videos 
yet. I have to agree on a nice compromise between Steve and Matt. With Tau, 
learning and understanding circles would be easier for students being 
introduced to them. But I think that durning the actual calculations, 
students should use it in terms of Pi. I know that if I were taught that 
2Pi = Tau, therefore Tau can nicely segment the circle, it would have made 
it easier to grasp. Thus calculations in terms of Pi would be simpler. But 
Matt made a great point that Pi is used as a unit, and Tau wouldn't be 
sensible since it IS the circle.

In short, they both have great arguments. But it's more effective to give 
perspective on both terms of thinking regarding circles, yet still using Pi 
calculations in order to keep it universal. ﻿

comments.text:
I'm for pi! And here's why (from a physics rather than Maths point of 
view). 

When you talk about interference of waves we use pi radians to describe if 
it's constructive or destructive interference. 
For destructive it's π radian out of phase it's destructive if it's 2π it's 
constructive. Using Tau will create fractions and really detracts from the 
unit. I agree with Matt, it makes more sense to use π as it allows it to be 
a better unit. Encompassing something takes something away. 
Pi is everywhere from Hawking's equations to Coulomb's law (where k is 
1/4πe0). It's for this reason that Steve's notion of it not being a just 
one unit is redundant. If we used Tau we'd get 4τ and 2τ so it doesn't 
actually "solve" anything.﻿

comments.text:
+Michael Anthony e^(iπ)=-1 gives insight into the rotating nature of i.
e^(iτ)=1 doesn't.


e^(iπ)=-1
e^(2iπ)=1
e^(3iπ)=-1
e^(4iπ)=1
e^(5iπ)=-1
and so on . . .


τ is just a multiple of π. What is the smallest positive real number x such 
that e^(ix) is an integer? It's none other than π. Were we to replace π 
with τ, we'd end up obfuscating the meaning of i (i.e. the connection i has 
with -1) in the equation.


e^(iτ)=1
e^(2iτ)=1
e^(3iτ)=1
e^(4iτ)=1
and so on . . .


Thus e^(iπ)=-1 gives us a more complete understanding than e^(iτ)=1, because


e^(iπ)=-1
e^(2iπ)=e^(iτ)=1
e^(3iπ)=-1
e^(4iπ)=e^(2iτ)=1
e^(5iπ)=-1
e^(6iπ)=e^(3iτ)=1
e^(7iπ)=-1
e^(8iπ)=e^(4iτ)=1


Now, where is τ when -1? π is more flexible. Raise e^(iπ) to an even 
integer and it becomes 1. Raise it to an odd integer and it, then, becomes 
-1, but e^(iτ) cannot be but 1 because τ is but a multiple of π. I would 
not be surprised if τ becomes part of a beautiful equation, since it's a 
multiple of π, but I would certainly be surprised if it usurps π.

comments.text:
+Michael Anthony You're wrong about the ugliness of e^(i pi) = -1 being the 
motivator for writing the equation as e^(ipi) +1 = 0. The latter identity 
is favorednot for the ugliness of other forms of the identity, but because 
e^(i pi) + 1 = 0 contains the additive and multiplicative identity, e, pi, 
AND i, as well as addition, multiplication and exponentiation making that 
form of the more general equation derived by Euler a one stop shop of 
algebra's top dogs. The form you showed, with tau or pi, loses the additive 
identity, the addition, and arguably the additive identity. I'm not 
agreeing with your or them on which form of the identity is most beautiful, 
but you can't say that you and others not using e^(i pi) = -1 implies that 
you and those others share the same motivation for not using that form.
